titleStmt.title: A Survey on Multi-objective Evolutionary Algorithms for the Solution of the Environmental/Economic Dispatch Problems

analytic.title: A Survey on Multi-objective Evolutionary Algorithms for the Solution of the Environmental/Economic Dispatch Problems

biblStruct.note: Received date: 21 July 2016 Revised date: 8 June 2017 Accepted date: 21 June 2017

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: Swarm and Evolutionary Computation Evolutionary algorithms (EAs)

div.p: Development of efficient multi-objective evolutionary algorithms (MOEAs) has provided effective tools to solve environmental/economic dispatch (EED) problems. EED is a highly constrained complex bi-objective optimization problem. Since 1990s, numerous publications have reported the applications of MOEAs to solve the EED problems. This paper surveys the state-of-the-art of research related to this direction.

It covers topics of typical MOEAs, classical EED problems, Dynamic EED problems, EED problems incorporating wind power, EED problems incorporating electric vehicles and EED problems within micro-grids. In addition, some potential directions for future research are also presented.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In recent decades, the highly constrained nonlinear multi-objective optimization problem known as environmental/economic dispatch (EED) problem has attracted research efforts due to the increasing concerns about environmental pollution. EED is a bi-objective problem with two conflicting objectives which are the minimization of generation cost and pollution emission. Various approaches have been reported in literature to handle the EED problem.
Initially, conventional optimization methods such as linear programming techniques were mainly used as the optimizing tool for solving the EED problem [1],

[2]. However, these methods are not effective when the dispatch problem becomes complex. Hence, researchers turned to artificial intelligent techniques especially evolutionary algorithms (EAs) and swarm algorithms (SAs). These metaheuristics use mechanisms inspired by Darwinian Theory of biological evolution and social interactions, respectively. The studies have shown that EAs and SAs can effectively overcome most of the drawbacks of classical method. EAs and SAs have been successfully adopted to solve various kinds of power dispatch problems [3]- [11].

Since EAs and SAs use a population of solutions to conduct the search process, multiple non-dominated solutions can be found in one single run. Moreover, EAs and SAs require few domain information of the given problem. These features are attractive for solving complex multi-objective EED optimization problems. Numerous multi-objective evolutionary algorithms (MOEAs) have been suggested to solve the EED problem [12]- [15]. The aim of this paper is to provide a broad view of using MOEAs in EED applications and encourage researchers in power application domains to benefit from further use of MOEAs. The taxonomy adopted in this paper is based on the topics reviewed and it is divided into 5 parts. The first one studies the classical EED problems using MOEAs while the remaining sections reviews other types of the EED applications.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 provides a brief introduction of multi-objective optimization and the state-of-the-art MOEAs. Sections 3-7 present MOEAs for the classical EED problems, Dynamic EED problems, EED problems with wind power, EED problems with electric vehicles and EED problems within a micro-grid, respectively. The paper is concluded in Section 8.

div.head: Multi-objective optimization
div.p: In this part, the basic concepts of multi-objective optimization and some typical MOEAs are introduced.

div.head: Formulation of Multi-objective Optimization problems
div.p: The multi-objective optimization problems (MOPs) can be mathematically formulated as follows assuming as minimization problems: To solve multi-objective optimization problems, the following concepts are essential.
Feasible solution set:

x satisfies all constraints, x is a feasible solution and the set of all feasible solutions is the feasible solution set, denoted as , if there does not exist another feasible solution X  x' satisfying x' x , we say that x is non-dominated with respect to X , and this feasible solution x is defined as a Pareto-optimal solution as *
x . The set of all Pareto-optimal solutions is defined as the Pareto-optimal set denoted as * P , i. e.,
Pareto-optimal front: The Pareto-optimal front is defined as Based on the above concepts, obtaining the Pareto-optimal set is the key task of multi-objective optimization algorithms.

div.head: Typical MOEAs for solving EED problem
div.p: EAs and SAs are stochastic optimization techniques inspired by the natural evolutionary and swarming processes. Due to their own properties, they are more suitable for solving MOPs than other conventional mathematical techniques. Since early 1990s, researchers proposed numerous Multi-objective Evolutionary Algorithms (MOEAs) and used them to solve complex MOPs. In this section, we aim to present a short review of some typical MOEAs especially those used for solving the EED problems. These MOEAs are presented in the chronological order.

div.head: Problem formulation
div.p: The prime target of traditionally electric power systems is to schedule the outputs of the generators to meet the load requirement with a minimum fuel cost regardless of emissions produced [1]. With the increasing requirements for the environmental protection, alternative operational strategies are needed to reduce the pollution of the electric power plants. Environmental/Economic Dispatch (EED) problems treat the pollution emissions and the fuel cost as two conflicting objectives which are optimized simultaneously subjected to the practical constraints. Generally, the problem can be formulated as follows:
Fuel cost objective: The cost curves of the generators can be represented by quadratic functions and the total fuel cost $/h can be expressed as:

F(P G ) is the total fuel cost of the system while N G identifies the number of thermal units. programming techniques which incorporated the techniques of section reduction method and third simplex method were used to tackle the EED problems. The methods were applied on the 10-bus model system as well as the 30-bus model system and the results showed that the proposed method could solve the problem effectively.

div.p: In [27] and [28], the EED problem was changed to a single objective problem by considering the emission as a constraint. However, this method cannot obtain the trade-off relations between the two objectives.

div.head: Weighted sum approaches
div.p: As mentioned in the previous section, linear combination of different objectives as a weighted sum is another commonly used approach [29]-[32] for solving multi-objective EED problems. In this method, the objectives are transformed into a single-objective problem by using suitable scalarization. This approach generally takes the following form of objective function:
div.formula:   G GG 1 min ( ) (1 ) ( ) N i i i i i F P E P       (8)
div.p: where  is the scaling factor which blends the emission objective with the fuel objective and  is the weight factor in the range of [0, 1]. Although this approach is easy to implement, it requires multiple runs by varying the weights to obtain the trade-off non-dominated solutions. With the development of multi-objective evolutionary algorithms (MOEAs), researchers frequently use MOEAs to solve the EED problems as introduced in detail in the subsequent section.

div.head: MOEA approaches
div.p: In recent years, researchers have handled both objectives of the EED problem simultaneously as competing objectives using MOEAs

div.head: DE-based approaches
div.p: In [24], a differential evolution (DE) based approach was used to solve the EED problem. To enable DE with the ability of handling multi-objective optimization problems, non-domination sorting and ranking selection procedures were adopted in the selection step. The simulation results showed its superior performance over NSGA The algorithm utilized the good exploration ability of DE and good exploitation ability of BBO to improve its performance.

div.head: Other evolutionary methods
div.p: In [12], a heuristics-guided evolutionary method was introduced to evaluate the economic impacts of environmental dispatching and fuel switching. Although this method handled both objectives at the same time, the stochastic competition between two individuals was only based on one randomly chosen objective. This approach can produce several alternatives along the Pareto-optimal front, but it cannot find the entire non-dominated Front. In [26], Abido adopted a Strength Pareto Evolutionary Algorithm (SPEA) based approach to tackle the two conflicting objectives. This algorithm embedded the same diversity-preserving mechanism and hierarchical clustering as in [14]- [19] to improve the solutions' quality.
In [42], a non-domination sorting based multi-objective evolutionary programming (MOEP) was proposed to show its superior performance over NSGA-II.

However, the non-domination sorting process is computationally expensive and time consuming. To overcome this problem, Qu et al. [56] used a fast sorting technique to replace the complex non-domination sorting. In [57], MOEP was also used as the optimization tool to solve the EED problems. However, the emissions were split into two separated objectives known as NO x emission objective and SO 2 emission objective and the EED was changed to a three-objective optimization problem.

In The algorithm adopted a non-dominated sorting and ranking procedure with dynamic crowding distance to locate and maintain the Pareto front. IEEE 30 bus and 118 bus systems were used to demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed algorithm.
In addition to the above-mentioned methods, there are also many other multi-objective backtracking search algorithm [73] and so on.

div.head: Typical systems and results
div.p: In the works reviewed above, 7 systems are commonly used as case studies and the descriptions of these systems are presented as follows:

System A: 6-generator 30-bus standard test system (Table 1) System B: 13-generator 57-bus system (Table 2) System C: 3-generator system (Table 3) System D: 6-generator system (Table 4) System E: 14-generator 118-bus system (Table 5) System F: 40-generator system (Table 6) System G: 10-generator system (Table 7) To provide a clear view of the systems used in different works, Table 8 summarizes the various methods mentioned in Section 3.1.2. As can be seen from this table, system A (6-generator 30-bus standard test system) is the most commonly used test system. Therefore, some typical results on this system are provided in Tables 91011121314.

Tables 8-11 present the results on 6-generator 30-bus lossless system without considering the security constraints while Tables 11-14 present the results on 6-generator 30-bus considering losses and all constraints. Note that Tables 10 and14 present the best compromise results for both cases. The best compromise results balance the two objectives and it is commonly used to compare different algorithms on the EED problems. The best compromise solution is obtained using a fuzzy-based mechanism and membership value of each solution in the final non-dominated set i F computed using the following membership function [33]: Fuel cost objective:

Ramping rate constraints: During conjoint dispatching time periods, each generator must satisfy certain ramping rate limit and this constraint can be model as:

Weighted sum approach is also commonly used to solve the DEED problem. In With the help of DHCH, the number of infeasible solutions was reduced significantly.
A similar constraint handling method was also incorporated into MOEA/D to solve the DEED problem considering wind power [89].

div.head: EED problems incorporating wind power
div.p: Wind power is a clean energy source which plays an increasing role in power generation [90]. It can reduce the pollution emissions as well as the dependence on fossil fuels. However, the stochastic nature of wind speed leads to an uncertainty on wind power output. Consequently, the high penetrations of wind power complicate the EED problems significantly.

In general, the research framework of the EED problems with wind power is based on the models described in the Sections 3.1 and 4.1. The difference is the wind power modeling methods which include deterministic modeling method, probabilistic modeling method and fuzzy modeling method. Note that most of the current works convert the wind power EED problem to a single objective one due to the complexity and uncertainty of wind power and its significant impact on environmental and economic objectives. In [90], the multi-objective EED problem was converted to a single objective optimization problem by the concept of Price Penalty Factors (PPFs).

The stochastic characteristic of wind power was expressed by the penalty cost of The wind energy is intermittent and uncertain which is highly coupled with time variable. Hence, compared with the traditional static dispatching model, the dynamic dispatching model is more suitable for the power system with wind integration. Liang

div.head: EED problems considering Electric Vehicles (EVs)
div.p: Considering the requirements for energy saving and environmental protection, some researchers investigated the EED problems with EVs. Although EVs need to charge from the power system, in V2G mode, EVs can also supply power to the system thereby increasing the complexity of the EED problem.

div.head: Conclusions and future directions
div.p: In this paper, research works aiming to solve the EED problem especially using multi-objective evolutionary algorithms have been surveyed. Typical MOEAs, classical EED problems, dynamic EED problems, EED problems considering wind power, EED problems considering electric vehicles and the EED problems within a micro-grid have been covered.

Although there have been numerous publications on the classical EED problems, the study of the EED problems using multi-objective evolutionary algorithms is still in its early stages. At present, there have been some achievements in solving the dynamic EED problem and the EED problem with wind power, while research on EED associated with micro-grids and EVs is limited. Modeling and solving of such EED problems are worthy of investigating especially using multi-objective evolutionary algorithms. Furthermore, the new scheduling modes (such as security dispatch and risk dispatch, etc.) and new application scenarios (such as virtual power plants and active distribution networks, etc.) continue to emerge in the recent years.
Developing the corresponding dispatch models and effective solution algorithms are important future research directions.

figure.figDesc: ) Vector Evaluated Genetic Algorithm (VEGA)[16]: VEGA is commonly known as the first MOEA. It modifies the original genetic algorithm to make it capable of handling multi-objective optimization problems. In VEGA, the population is divided into several subpopulations and the number of subpopulations is equal to the number of objectives. Each subpopulation is responsible for searching one objective. While the concept of this algorithm is straightforward, the solutions obtained by this technique are usually not uniformly distributed along the Pareto front especially in the tradeoff regions.(2) Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm (NSGA) [14], [17]: NSGA was introduced by Srinivas and Deb in 1994. This method uses ranking selection and niching techniques to find the non-dominated solutions and maintain the diversity of the population. Two main steps are involved in this method known as fitness assignment and fitness sharing. Fitness assignment helps fast convergence while fitness sharing increase the diversity. (3) Multi-Objective Stochastic Search Technique (MOSST) [13]: The MOSST heuristic has been designed as a combination of real coded genetic algorithm (GA) and simulated annealing (SA) techniques. It incorporates a genetic crossover operator BLX-α and a problem specific mutation operator with a local search heuristic to provide a better search capability [13]. It can offer the advantages of both GA and SA. (4) Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II) [18]: NSGA-II is the most popular multi-objective evolutionary algorithm. The dominance concept is used in NSGA-II to sort/rank the solutions. Moreover, it uses crowding distance to estimate the density of solutions near each solution. NSGA-II uses both the non-domination rank and crowding distance to select individuals to survive to the next generation.(5) Niched Pareto Genetic Algorithm (NPGA) [19]: NPGA uses Pareto domination tournaments selection scheme to find the good solutions and remove the bad ones. Different from the method used in [17], only two candidates are randomly picked for tournament each time. To compare the two candidates, a randomly selected comparison set is used. Then, the dominance of both individuals with respect to the comparison set is checked. Sharing procedure will be used if both individuals are dominated by the comparison set. (6) Multi-objective Particle Swarm Optimization (MOPSO) [20]: MOPSO is a variation of the PSO to solve MOPs [21]. Determining global best (gbest) is the key issue of MOPSO. MOPSO uses the non-dominated solutions as the basis of selecting the gbest. The algorithm maintains two archives to save the global best individuals found so far and the local bests, respectively. The selection of a global best is based on roulette wheel selection of a hypercube score [22]. (7) Multi-Objective Evolutionary Algorithm based on Decomposition (MOEA/D) [23]: MOEA/D was introduced by Zhang et al. in 2007. It provides a new framework to solve MOPs. MOEA/D handles an MOP by decomposing it into numerous single objective sub-problems and optimizes the sub-problems using evolutionary approach collaboratively and concurrently. (8) Multi-objective Differential Evolution (MODE) [24]: MODE is like the basic DE algorithm expect the selection process. Generally, MODE adopts the non-dominated sorting and ranking selection methods developed by Deb et al. [18]. The non-dominated sorting is performed on the combined population of new generated offspring and parents and the selection is based on the non-dominated rank and crowding distance. Other techniques like summation based sorting and diversified selection were also proposed and used in the literature [25].

[33]. The evolutionary algorithms have shown that they are able to overcome most of the disadvantages of the classical methods [25]-[35]. Since evolutionary algorithms are population based optimization techniques, multiple optimal solutions can be found in one single run. This feature is attractive for solving the EED problems, as multiple solutions need to be located to form the non-dominated front. Using MOEAs to solve the EED problems can be traced back to early 1990s [12],[13]. Since then MOEAs have become the main technique for solving the EED problems. The aim of this section is to provide a review of the works that used MOEAs to solve the EED problems in the past few decades. These works are presented based on the search techniques namely, Genetic Algorithm (GA) based approaches, Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) based approaches, Differential Evolution (DE) based approaches, hybrid approaches and other evolutionary approaches.3.3.1 GA based approachesIn [14], [36], a modified Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm (NSGA) based method was proposed. It employed a diversity-preserving technique to prevent premature convergence. This approach also imposed a hierarchical clustering technique to generate a representative and manageable Pareto-optimal set. In 2003, similar diversity-preserving and hierarchical clustering mechanisms were incorporated into a Niched Pareto Genetic Algorithm (NPGA) [19]. This algorithm used a Pareto domination tournament selection scheme to find the non-dominated set of solutions. In 2006, Abido [33] performed a comprehensive comparative discussion on using different MOEAs (specifically, NSGA, NPGA and SPEA) to solve the EED problems. In [37], a multi-objective genetic algorithm based on the concept of epsilon-dominance was introduced to solve the EED problems. The epsilon-dominance was applied to members in the archive where the solutions are stored and it improved the solution quality and convergence characteristics. In [38], Harry and Robert used NSGA-II to overcome the weakness of NSGA. Similarly, Guesmi et al. [39] also demonstrated the superior performance of NSGA-II over NSGA and NPGA. In [40], a modified NSGA-II that utilized the Dynamic Crowding Distance (DCD) and Controlled Elitism (CE) techniques was proposed to overcome the drawbacks of poor diversity of the original NSGA-II. The modified NSGA-II was tested and compared on the IEEE 14-, 30-, 57-and 118-bus systems. In [41], a similar NSGA-II method was used to solve the EED problems.3.3.2 PSO based approachesPSO based methods are one of the most popular approaches for solving the EED problems. In[20], an external memory based Multi-objective Particle Swarm Optimization (MOPSO) was adopted. Two external memories called repositories were maintained in addition to the search population in this method. One was used to store the global best individuals while the other one was for the local best of each particle. This algorithm also used a geographically-based technique to maintain the diversity of the obtained solutions. In 2009, Abiod also adopted MOPSO technique to handle the EED problems[42]. In this work, the global best and local best were redefined using the non-domination concept which could lead the particles to locate the Pareto front effectively. Similar methods can also be found in[43].In 2007,Wang and Singh [44] proposed a Fuzzified Multi-Objective Particle Swarm Optimization (FMOPSO) to preserve the diversity of the solutions when dealing with the EED problems. This method treated the global best not just as a point but as an area and each point in this area had different possibilities to be selected as the global best. A fuzzy clustering-based multi-objective particle swarm algorithm (FCPSO) was proposed to solve theEED problem in 2008 [45]. This algorithm incorporated niching mechanism to direct the particles to search the less explored regions of the Pareto front. It also used a self-adaptive mutation operator to enhance the diversity of the solutions.In[47], a multi-objective chaotic particle swarm optimization (MOCPSO) was developed and proven to be more effective than conventional MOPSO for solving the EED problems. In 2012, a parameter-free multi-objective particle swarm optimization algorithm called bare-bones MOPSO (BB-MOPSO) was proposed to solve EED problems[48]. The results showed BB-MOPSO outperforming seven MOEAs and three well-known MOPSO techniques on the IEEE 30-bus test system. Recently,Liu et al. [46] introduced a cultural quantum-behaved particle swarm optimization (CMOQPSO) algorithm to solve the EED problems. In this algorithm, the cultural evolution mechanism was used to enhance its global searching ability while a local search operator was used to enhance its local searching ability. CMOQPSO is tested on the 6-and 40-generator systems, respectively to demonstrate its effectiveness.

33] and SPEA[33]. Similarly,Basu [49] also demonstrated the effectiveness of MODE algorithms for solving the EED problems. Wu et al. presented a modified MODE that adopted an external elitist archive and a crowding entropy strategy to store the non-dominated solutions and maintain the diversity in2010 [50]. This algorithm was used to solve the IEEE 30-bus and 118-bus test systems and it was proven to be effective in solving the EED problems. In[51], an enhanced multi-objective differential evolution algorithm was proposed to solve the EED problems. This algorithm adopted an elitist archive technique to store the non-dominated solutions and the DE operators were modified according to the characteristics of the problems. To prevent premature convergence, this algorithm introduced a local random search operator to improve its convergence performance.3.3.4 Hybrid approachesHybridizing different EA techniques is a commonly used approach to utilize the advantages of different EAs for dealing with complicated optimization problems. Das and Patvardhan [13] introduced one of the earliest hybrid multi-objective evolutionary algorithms called Multi-Objective Stochastic Search Technique (MOSST) to solve the EED problems. MOSST was designed as a combination of the real coded genetic algorithms and simulated annealing. It also incorporated a local search technique to provide a better search capability. However, this approach suffers from severe premature convergence problem. In 2010, Gong et al. introduced a hybrid MOEA based on the techniques of PSO and DE [52]. This algorithm utilized PSO as the global searching tool while DE was used as the local search tool. The combination of PSO and DE strengthens both the exploration and exploitation of the algorithm when solving the EED problems. In 2010, a modified NSGA-II which integrated a Convergence Accelerator Operator (CAO) into the original NSGA-II was proposed by Alawode to solve the EED problems [53]. The CAO consisted of two steps which were a deterministic local improvement procedure and a neural network based procedure. The modified NSGA-II was proven to be more effective than the original NSGA-II. In [54], [55] a combination of differential evolution and biogeography-based optimization (BBO) algorithm was developed to improve the convergence speed as well as the solution quality when solving the EED problems.

[58], a multi-objective chaotic ant swarm optimization (MOCASO) method was developed to solve three different test power systems. In 2010, Hota et al. presented a fuzzy based bacterial foraging algorithm that utilized the successful foraging strategies of the global optimum bacterium and showed its robustness and reliability in handling the EED problems [59]. In the same year, Panigrahi et al. [60] proposed a fuzzy dominance based bacterial foraging algorithm to tackle the EED problems. This algorithm obtained the most recent bacterial locations by using the chemotaxis process and the fuzzy dominance based sorting technique was used to select the Pareto optimal front. In 2011 [61], Panigrahi et al. further modified the multi-objective bacteria foraging algorithm by using the intermediate bacteria positions during chemotaxis. In [62], Hemamalini and Simon developed a multi-objective artificial bee colony algorithm which used the non-domination sort in the ranking and selection process to solve the standard IEEE 30 bus system [62]. In [63], a multi-objective directed bee colony optimization algorithm was developed to handle the EED problems. This algorithm is a hybrid version of deterministic search, multi-agent system and bee decision-making process and it used a modified Nelder-Mead method to find the optimal solutions. In [64], Niknam et al. handled the EED problems using a modified shuffle frog leaping algorithm. This algorithm used a strong mutation technique to increase the population diversity. In 2011, Sivasubramani and Swarup developed a multi-objective harmony search (MOHS) algorithm to solve the EED problems [65].

evolutionary and swarm methods proposed in the literature to handle the EED problems in the recent years. These methods include biogeography based optimization [66], Interactive honey bee mating optimization [67], cultural algorithm [68], bacterial colony chemotaxis optimization algorithm [69], adaptive clonal selection algorithm [70], scatter search [71], quasi-oppositional teaching learning based optimization [72],

The best compromise solution is that for which [

Dispatch (DEED) is an extension of the classical EED problem which takes into consideration of the ramping rate constraints of the generators [75]-[79]. Optimization of the DEED problem schedules the outputs of online generator with the predicted load demands over a period [75]. The DEED problem is much more complex than the classical EED problem due to the large number of variables and constraints. This section presents an introduction to the DEED problem as well as the state-of-the-art MOEA approaches for solving the DEED problem. 4.1 Problem formulation Differences between the DEED and the EED problem formulations are incorporation of the time variables. The detailed description of the DEED model is as follows:

11], Nwulu and Xia combined the DEED problem with game theory based demand (DR) response programs. This work optimized three objectives (minimize the fuel and emissions costs and maximize the utility demand response benefit) simultaneously and the results showed that the method was an efficient way to reduce demand in the power system. In [80], three versions of Differential Harmony Search (DHS) algorithms were used to solve the DEED problem. In this work, the weights were varied in steps and each variation generated one compromise solution. The best compromise solution was selected by using a fuzzy based method. 4.3 MOEA approaches to solve DEED In 2008, Basu applied NSGA-II to solve the DEED problem as a true multi-objective optimization problem with non-commensurable and competing objectives [76]. The algorithm was verified on the 10-unit test system with non-smooth fuel cost and emission level functions. The predicted load demands of the system were divided into 24 intervals (hourly generation schedule) and the simulation results showed that NSGA-II was able to generate superior performance over classical techniques. Guo et al. introduced a multi-objective evolutionary method called group search optimizer with multiple producers (GSOMP) to handle the DEED problem [81]. The algorithm adopted the constrained tournament method [82] and Lamarckian method [83] to handle the inequality and equality constraints, respectively. Technique for Order Preference Similar to an ideal solution (TOPSIS) was developed to find the final solution from the non-dominated solutions according to a decision maker's preference. The simulation results demonstrated that GSOMP could achieve better convergence and diversity performance than MOPSO and NSGA-II. In [84], the DEED problem considering hourly load and wind power was solved using a multi-objective particle swarm optimization algorithm. Incorporation of the wind power changes the DEED problem into a stochastic problem. A two-stage scenario-based method was used to convert the problem into its respective deterministic equivalents first and solved subsequently. Similar problems were also investigated by Bahmanifirouzi et al. using particle swarm optimization based algorithms [85], [86]. In [87], Niknam et al. proposed a theta-multi-objective teaching-learning-based optimization to solve DEED problem. The algorithm incorporated several modifications such as phase angles based optimization process to improve its performance. Moreover, the algorithm used a niching mechanism to allocate more searching resources to less explored regions. In [88], a multi-objective differential evolution algorithm with expanded double selection and adaptive random restart was applied to solve the DEED. The expanded double selection was proposed to strengthen the global search ability while the adaptive random restart was proposed to use the elitist information of the non-dominated solutions saved in the external archive. This work also introduced a Dynamic Heuristic Constraint Handling (DHCH) technique to deal with the complicated constraints. DHCH was employed to handle the equality constraints through an iterative correction process of infeasible solutions.

overestimating and underestimating for wind turbines. An optimization technique, called Gravitational Search Algorithm (GSA), was applied to solve the complex optimization problem. In [91], Yao et al. solved the stochastic EED model considering wind power probability and carbon emission tax by using the Quantum-inspired Particle Swarm Optimization (QPSO) method.

et al.[92] established a dynamic model considering wind power with emission constraint and proposed a GA based fuzzy-optimization approach to handle it.Jadhav et al. [93] used a single objective dynamic model to demonstrate the overall operation cost of conventional and wind power generators. The emission was converted to cost using carbon tax value, and the Gbest guided Artificial Bee Colony (GABC) algorithm was applied.Lee et al. [94] added the emission to the general operation cost by using environmental coefficient and the wind power was treated as common load.The Quantum Genetic Algorithm (QGA) was employed to solve the problem. In [95], the spinning reserve compensation cost owing to the random nature of the wind resources was included and an optimization algorithm based Chaotic Quantum Genetic Algorithm (CQGA) was proposed to solve the economic dispatch problem with wind energy. In[96], the Weibull distribution and the probability density functions were used to calculate the underestimated and overestimated unbalance cost of wind power considering its uncertainty, and a Bi-Population Chaotic Differential Evolution (BPCDE) algorithm was proposed to solve the wind-thermal dispatching problem.As mentioned before, most of the above methods converted the multi-objective EED problem to a single objective one, thereby ignoring the importance of Pareto-optimality in the dispatch decision making process. In the recent few years, some works have reported the usage of MOEAs to solve the EED problems considering wind power. Abul'Wafa [97] established a multi-objective EED model that included the cost of modern thermal units with valves point effect, the polluting gas emission and the factor for both overestimation and underestimation of available wind. NSGA-II was used as the optimizer to solve this model. In [98], a multi-objective energy dispatch model considered environmental and fuel cost under large wind energy was proposed. The wind power was treated as a common load as in[94] and an effective encoding/decoding scheme for the SPEA procedure was used to improve the performance. In [99], a summation based multi-objective differential evolution (SMODE) algorithm was adopted to optimize the EED problem with stochastic wind power. This work used Weibull probability distribution function to model the stochastic nature of the wind power and the uncertainty is treated as system constraints. In [100], an online learning meta-heuristic method was used to optimize the EED problem with wind power units. The uncertainty of wind power was estimated using a practical model known as 2m-point. In [101], the multi-objective dynamic economic emission dispatch problem integrating wind power was researched with a scenario-based stochastic programming framework to model the random nature of load demand and wind forecast errors. Moreover, a novel Fuzzy Adaptive Improved Particle Swarm Optimization (FAIPSO) algorithm was used to obtain the best solution for the corresponding scenarios. In [102], a stochastic approach based on scenarios for the uncertainties associated with hourly load and wind power forecasts was built for DEED problem incorporating wind power plant. A Fuzzy Self Adaptive Learning Particle Swarm Optimization (FSALPSO) algorithm was developed to solve the problem. In [103], the wind power generators were modeled by a piecewise linear approximation while the 2m-point estimatation and modified teaching-learning algorithm were used to obtain the set of non-dominated optimal solutions.

In [104], [105], Saber et al. proposed a typical EED model for both cost and emission optimization with a single objective function. In this model, the V2G behaviors were characterized by the "registered" numbers and present/departure SoC (State of Charge) of EVs. The PSO was used to generate the optimal dispatch schedule and control of EVs. Using the similar methods, Gholami et al. [106] established an EED model with a combined economic and emission objective by using cost and emission coefficients. PSO was also adopted as the optimizer. Based on the above work, Debnath et al. [107] presented a system model considering EV's battery lifetime. In [108], the multi-objective DEED problem was also transformed into a single objective problem and a self-learning teaching-learning based optimization (TLBO) algorithm was employed to obtain the dispatching scheme. In [109], a dynamic economic dispatching model with EVs for smart grid was constructed. In this model, the minimization of power generation costs, the lowest charging cost of EVs' owners, the least air pollution and maximization of synthetic load ratio were taken as objectives and the NSGA-II algorithm was used to solve the problem.7. EED problems within a micro-gridMicro-grid is the key component of the Smart-grid of the future and it has become an active research area in the recent years. In[110], a Fuzzy Self Adaptive Particle Swarm Optimization (FSAPSO) algorithm was proposed to solve the EED in a typical micro-grid considering economy and emission as competing objectives. In[111], the Multi-objective Mesh Adaptive Direct Search (MOMADS) was employed to minimize the cost and emission objectives of a micro-grid system. In[112], the chaotic quantum genetic algorithm method was used to solve the dynamic EED problem where the emissions were converted to costs. In[113], a two-stage method for micro-grid system was presented to minimize the total net present cost and carbon dioxide emission simultaneously in a life circle. On the first stage, NSGA-II was applied to solve the optimal design problem while on the second stage; the Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP) algorithm was used to solve the optimal dispatch problem. In [114],Motevasel et al. proposed an efficient Modified Bacterial Foraging Optimization (MBFO) algorithm to minimize both the total operation costs and the net emission in a micro-grid system.

Power balance constraint: the total power generation must cover the sum of total demands and the real power losses. This constraint can be mathematically expressed as: G G D loss 1 0 N i i P P P      (5) max G G G i i i P P P  (6) Security constraints: For a secure operation, the transmission line loading S l should be restricted by its upper limit [14], [19]: max | | , 1, 2,..., ii l l L S S i N  (7) 3.2 In early days, the EED problems are generally handled by including emissions either as a constraint or as a weighted function in the objective of the overall dispatching problem [1]. In [1], several methods/algorithms were introduced to solve the EED problems including fuel switching techniques. Fuel switching is either Generation capacity constraint: min switching the types of the fuel or lowering the sulfur content in the fuel. In [2], linear
